text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Opposition politicians stick to demands for constitutional reform.
- U.S. envoy Warren Christopher meets three East African heads of state on regional political and economic cooperation.
- A major project is set in motion by well-connected politicians which analysts say could be used to rip off 10 billion shillings from petroleum levy funds.
- British food products are being imported into Kenya and put on sale without the knowledge or permission of the firm.
- Somali factions in Nairobi hold talks in preparation for another meeting in four days.
- The High Court questions the seriousness of two warring opposition party factions in resolving a leadership saga.
- New Iveti Coffee Farmers' Cooperative storm Distict Commissioner's office protesting alleged mysterious disappearance of more than 49 million shillings.
- Court of Appeal sets free two conficts who had been on death row for 10 years after being sentenced to death for armed robbery.
- Kenya Commercial Bank says it is malicious for individuals or groups to drag its name into the woes of Kenya Cooperative Creameries.
